questions.text: You are conducting a cohort study in a group of headload workers to identify the risk factors for developing low back pain in future. This type of study falls under which of the following?
questions.solution:
Cohort studies fall under non-experimental (observational) analytical studies.

Classification of epidemiological studies:

  1. Observational studies: allow nature to take its own course, the investigator measures but does not intervene. It is further classified into:
    • Descriptive studies: limited to describing the occurrence of a disease in a population.
    • Analytical studies: go further by analyzing the relationship between health status and other variables. It includes:
      • Ecological studies
      • Cross-sectional studies
      • Case-control studies
      • Cohort studies
  2. Experimental studies or interventional studies: it involves an active attempt to change a disease determinant or the progress of a disease, and is similar in design to experiments in other sciences.
    • Randomized controlled trials
    • Field trials
    • Community trials

questions.text: What is the unit of observation in ecological studies?
questions.solution:
In ecological studies, the unit of observation is the population or community.

Type of study Unit
Ecological/ Correlational Population
Cross-sectional/ Prevalence Individual
Case-control/ Case reference Individual
Cohort/ Follow up Individual
Randomised Controlled Trials Patients
Field Trial Healthy people
Community trial Community

questions.text: Identify the type of study from the following design:
questions.solution:
The design given is of a case-control study. It proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the exposure and outcome have occurred.

It tries to determine the possible exposure factors after a known disease incidence. This is the first approach to test causal hypotheses and uses controls to support or refute an inference.

Retrospective or historical cohort study, on the other hand, tries to compare the risk of developing a disease to some already known exposure factors. Ex: risk of lung cancer in uranium miners, risk of angiosarcoma in persons exposed to polyvinyl chloride etc.

Retrospective cohort studies are more economical and quicker than prospective cohort studies.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: A study was conducted among a group of 500 patients with lung cancer and another group of 300 people chosen from the general population. Both the groups were questioned about their exposure to smoking. What kind of study is this?
questions.solution:
This is a case-control study. In this scenario, 500 patients constitute the cases and 300 people from the general population constitute the controls. The study is done from effect (lung cancer) to cause (smoking).

questions.text: A case-control study was conducted to evaluate the association between lifestyle risk factors and the prevalence of dyslipidemia. Which of the following is not an advantage of this type of study?
questions.solution:
Incidence cannot be calculated from case-control studies. Incidence can be calculated from cohort studies, also known as longitudinal studies.

questions.text: A case-control study was conducted to see if symptoms of upper gastrointestinal dysfunction occurred more frequently in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Which of the following cannot be used as controls in this study?
questions.solution:
Siblings cannot be used as controls while studying genetic conditions because the outcome would be distorted due to their similarities.

Controls in a case-control study:

  • Usually disease-free
  • Can be up to 4 times the number of cases in small studies
  • In large studies, a 1:1 ratio of cases and controls can be sought
  • Sources: general population, hospitals, relatives (spouses and siblings), neighbors, or colleagues
  • Although, siblings cannot be used as controls for studies on genetic conditions

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of bias in a case-control study?
questions.solution:
Hawthorne bias is not seen in case-control studies. This bias occurs when the subjects change their attitude/ actions while under observation. This distorts the results of the cohort or experimental studies.

The bias that are seen in the case-control study are:

  1. Confounding
  2. Recall bias
  3. Selection bias
  4. Berkesonian bias
  5. Interviewer's bias

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about random errors?

choices.text: Systematic errors are different from random errors

questions.solution:
Random errors are not causes of bias. 

Random error arises when a value of the sample measurement diverges, due to chance alone, from that of the true population value. They can never be completely eliminated. 

Sources of random errors are individual biological variations, sampling errors, and measurement errors.

Systematic errors are also called biases. They are different from random errors.

questions.text: Which of the following factors in a study will cause Berkesonian bias?

choices.text: Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects
Different rates of hospital admission of different diseases
Researcher's belief in the treatment changing the outcome of the study
Cases that are lost to follow-up

questions.solution:

questions.text: An epidemiologist plans to conduct a prospective study instead of a retrospective study. Which of the following disadvantages does he aim to eliminate by conducting this study?
questions.solution:
Recall bias can be eliminated in a prospective study.

Recall bias is also called memory bias. It is widely seen in retrospective (case-control) studies as extensive history is taken from the participants.

questions.text: A study conducted in a group revealed that consumption of alcohol increases the risk of esophageal cancer, but it may be actually due to cigarette smoking. This happens due to:
questions.solution:
In this scenario, cigarette smoking is related to both the outcome of esophageal cancer and consumption of alcohol. Thus, this is an example of a confounding factor.

A confounding factor is defined as one which is associated with both exposure and outcome and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. In this study to determine the role of alcohol in the etiology of esophageal cancer, smoking is considered as a confounding factor because:

  • It is associated with the consumption of alcohol (exposure).
  • It is an independent risk factor for oesophageal cancer (outcome).

In these conditions, the effects of alcohol consumption can be determined only if the influence of smoking is neutralized by matching.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding confounding factor?

choices.text: It can be reduced by matching
It is associated individually with both cause and effect
It is distributed equally in both study and control groups
It is associated with the exposure of the study

questions.solution:
A confounding factor is a factor that is associated with both exposure and diseases and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. It can be reduced by matching.

For example, if the study is that a sedentary lifestyle can lead to coronary artery diseases, then age can act as a confounding factor as it is individually linked to both sedentary lifestyle and coronary artery diseases.

questions.text: A researcher is planning to conduct a study to investigate the relationship between oral contraceptives and breast cancer. He wants to remove age as a confounding factor. Which of the following methods will not help him reduce this bias?
questions.solution:
Deletion is not a method to reduce confounding.

Methods to reduce confounding are:

  • At the time of designing the study:
    • Randomization
    • Matching
    • Restriction
  • At the time of analysis:
    • Stratification
    • Statistical modelings like regression analysis, multivariate analysis, and the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel method.

questions.text: Matching is done for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Matching helps only in removing the known confounding factors.

Matching is the process by which controls are selected in a way that they are similar to cases in certain pertinent variables (e.g., age) that are known to influence the outcome of the disease. If not adequately matched for comparability, these variables could confound the results.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a type of matching?
questions.solution:
There is no type of matching called collective matching. 

Types of matching:

  • Group matching: It is also called frequency matching. It is done when a large stratum is used for study and a 1:1 ratio of cases and controls can be achieved.
  • Individual matching: It is also called matching by pairs. It can be done when the study is small and more controls can be selected for one case.

questions.text: An epidemiologist determines to evaluate the strength of association between asbestos exposure and mesothelioma in a case-control study. Which of the following variables would he use for it?
questions.solution:
Odds ratio (OR), also known as cross-product ratio, is used to measure the strength of association between risk factor (asbestos exposure) and outcome (mesothelioma) in case-control studies.

A case-control study yields only odds ratio and not incidence or relative risk.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the odds ratio?

choices.text: It is obtained from case-control studies
It is a measure of strength of association

questions.solution:
An odds ratio (OR) of 1 indicates that there is no association or that the event is likely in both the groups.

questions.text: A research scholar is preparing to do a prospective cohort study in a hospital to evaluate the association of H. pylori with inflammatory bowel disease. Which of the following measures must she take, before starting the study?

choices.text: Enrol all patients taking proton pump inhibitors
Enrol all patients on whom endoscopy was done
Exclude all patients diagnosed with inflammatory bowel disease
Exclude all patients with positive urea breath test for H. pylori

questions.solution:
All patients diagnosed with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) must be excluded from a prospective cohort study, as the study progresses from cause to effect. The study begins before the disease under study has occurred.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about cohort study?

choices.text: It is always a prospective study design
Outcome is not present at the start of study

questions.solution:
Although cohort studies are called prospective studies, there are subtypes of cohort studies that do not follow the prospective study design like historical (retrospective) cohort studies.

Framingham Heart Study is one of the most famous long-term cardiovascular prospective cohort studies.

questions.solution:
The ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is calledÂ relative risk (RR).

questions.text: Calculate the risk ratio when the incidence of the disease in exposed is 30 and that in non-exposed is 5.

questions.text:
While testing the deleterious health hazards on a group of people after giving a new drug and a placebo, the following results were obtained as tabulated. Based on these results, which of the following is true?
  Total participants People affected
New drug 15225 1603
Placebo 15225 1804

choices.text: Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 1% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 0.1
Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 10% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 0.9
Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 1% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 10
Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 10% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 9

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 1% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 0.1.

Let us reconstruct the design table in the following way:

  Health hazard (+) Health hazard (-) Total
New drug 1603 (a) 13622 (b) 15225 (a+b)
Placebo 1804 (c) 13421 (d) 15225 (c+d)

Relative risk (RR) is given as a/(a+b) ÷ c/(c+d).

RR = 1603/15225 ÷ 1804/15225 = 0.106/0.118 = 0.89 ≈ 0.90. 

Relative risk reduction (RRR) = 1 – Relative risk. In this scenario, RRR = 1 – 0.9 = 0.1 or 10%.

Incidence of a disease is the absolute risk of contracting it.

Absolute risk rate of the group using new drug = a/(a+b) = 1603/15225 = 0.106 or 10.6% ≈ 11%.

Absolute risk rate of the group using placebo = c/(c+d) = 1804/15225 = 0.118 or 11.8% ≈ 12%.

Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is the difference in the absolute risk rates between the placebo and the drug. In this scenario, ARR = 12% - 11% = 1%.

questions.text: A study found that the incidence of bladder carcinoma is 5 times higher in smokers than in non smokers. Calculate the attributable risk.
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the attributable risk (AR) is 80%.

Taking the incidence of disease in non-exposed as x, the incidence of disease in exposed would be 5x. 

Attributable risk (AR) would be given as [(5x - x)/5x] x 100 = 80%.

questions.text: Which of the following is the numerator in the formula for population-attributable risk?

choices.text: Incidence among exposed minus incidence among non-exposed
Incidence among non-exposed minus incidence among exposed
Incidence in the total population minus incidence among non-exposed
Incidence in the total population minus incidence among exposed

questions.solution:
Incidence in the total population minus incidence among non-exposedÂ is the numerator in population-attributable risk (PAR).

Population attributable risk is obtained from cohort studies. It provides an estimate of the amount by which the disease could be reduced in that population if the suspected factor was eliminated or modified.

questions.text: A study was done in the Indian population to correlate the deaths due to myocardial infarction and dietary practices. What is this type of study known as?
questions.solution:
This is an example of an ecological study. As the study was done in the Indian population, it can be inferred that population was taken as the unit of the study.

The study was done to correlate the deaths and dietary practices, and hence ecological studies are also called correlational studies.

questions.text: Which among the following is the weakest study design to prove causation?
questions.solution:
Ecological studies take a population as a unit. They provide the weakest evidence for causality because of extrapolation to individuals from regional data.

Randomized control trials (RCTs) provide the strongest design amongst the options given. Case-control and cohort studies have moderate ability to provide evidence for causality.

questions.text: What kind of bias is implied by assigning group characteristics to people which they may not possess as individuals?
questions.solution:
An ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.
